main_text.text: All right, today we are going to be talking, we've been going on about the benefits of AI, the complexity of AI and now let's talk a little bit about the environmental cost of AI.

main_text.text: First off, there's a reason why we keep pushing harder and harder.

main_text.text: And this is from that same situational awareness paper I talked about before.

main_text.text: And then there are what this particular researcher called unhobbling rather than having like we had in earlier LLMs, not current generation but earlier LLMs where it doesn't remember what you've talked about before and it's kind of going tabula rasa every time.

main_text.text: It will be better if it could kind of learn you and your, and your interests and your, and hopefully not make it into an echo chamber.

main_text.text: So that extraction especially of rare earth elements and certain other minerals like cobalt becomes a real limiting factor.

main_text.text: And so in 2014, Amnesty International found that around 20% of the cobalt being extracted from the DRC came from mines that use child labor.

main_text.text: And so Apple in 2017 pledged to treat cobalt as a conflict mineral as well and try and reform its supply chain to be able to eliminate child labor in ethnic practice and trying to reflect recover rare earth elements instead of trying to rely solely on life.
